value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">4</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">we should see tracks across the fields 
            <choice>
              <sic>joing</sic>
              <corr>joining</corr>
            </choice> manor house to</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">hovel, and hovel to church. Some of those paths of course</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">were worn by 
            <choice>
              <sic>soliders</sic>
              <corr>soldiers</corr>
            </choice> and
            <choice>
              <sic>labouerers</sic>
              <corr>labourers</corr>
            </choice>. They must fight to</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>gether</sic>
              <corr>gather</corr>
            </choice> and plough together if they were not to be conquered</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">by man and by nature. That connection isxx as time goes on</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and the <add hand="ms" place="above">[he? her?] <del hand="ms">me</del> records the daily struggle</add><del hand="ms">classes separate themselves</del>, is still painfully</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">recorded in old letter books and ledgers. It makes the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">staple of the old 
            <choice>
              <sic>corresp ondence</sic>
              <corr>correspondence</corr>
            </choice> between the <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-past" key="Pastons">Pastons</rs></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-norf" key="Norfolk">Norfolk</rs> and the <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-bets" key="Betsons">Betsons</rs> and <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-payc" key="Paycockes">Paycockes</rs> of <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-esse" key="Essex">Essex</rs>.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But there was also the the other less visible connection</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">--the common belief. That track between the houses in the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">village has been grown over<add hand="ms" place="inline">;-</add> like the track along which the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="literary-work" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#lit-cant" key="Canterbury Tales, The">pilgrims</rs> rode to <rs type="place" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#pla-cant" key="Canterbury"/>.--no one rides that way now.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">But before <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-gcha" key="Chaucer, Geoffrey">Chaucers</rs> time thxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it was trod daily. <add hand="ms" place="above">which</add> It led <del hand="ms">the peasants</del> to the tree</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to the well. In spring it led to the Maypole, where they</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">danced and sung Anons song. At Midsummer they lit the bon</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>fir</sic>
              <corr>fire</corr>
            </choice> on the hill. At Christmas the mummers acted the old</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Anons old play; and the boys came singing his wassailing</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">song. The road led to the old graves, to the stones where</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in time past the English had done sacrifice. The <choice>
            <sic>peasnts</sic>
            <corr>peasants</corr>
          </choice>,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">led by anon, still went that way by instinct, in spring</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and summer and winter. The old Gods lay hidden beneath the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">new. It was to them led by Anon that they did worship,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">in their coats of green leaves, bearing swords in their hands</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">dancing through the houses, enacting their ancient parts.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">It was the <rs type="object" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#obj-pres">printing press</rs> <del>in 1477</del> that k <add hand="ms" place="above">finally was to kill</add></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Anon. but it was the press also that preserved him. When</l>
